passage_en: Katharine Houghton Hepburn (May 12, 1907 Hartford, Connecticut – June 29, 2003 Old Saybrook, Connecticut) was an American film actress. She was nicknamed "First Lady of Cinema". In her more than 60-year career, Hepburn was nominated for an Oscar 12 times (among other actresses, only Meryl Streep has been more often) and received the award four times, more than any other actress. Hepburn became famous especially for her numerous films with Cary Grant and Spencer Tracy. In 1999, the American Film Institute chose her as the most outstanding actress of the century. passage_en: Thrasyllus of Mendes, full name Tiberius Claudius Thrasyllus (d. 36 CE) was an Egyptian astrologer, astronomer and mathematician who lived during the reign of Emperor Tiberius and served under him. He was known for the accuracy of his astronomical calculations. Today, Thrasyllus is best known for publishing one of the earliest complete editions of Plato's works and arranging Plato's works into tetralogies, or groups of four works. According to Diogenes Laertius, Thrasyllus had claimed that Plato himself organized the dialogues into tetralogies in the same way that Greek plays were organized into groups of four acts, each containing three tragedies and one satyr play. His thinking, under the name of Thomism, is still the basis of the theology and ethics of the Catholic Church. The man is respected in Catholicism, Anglicanism and Lutheranism. passage_en: Functionalism (from the Latin word "functio" 'function, task'; colloquially also "funkis" or "funkis") is a stylistic trend in architecture and design, as well as a method of modern architecture and design, according to which a building or object should be designed so that its parts serve each other specific purpose as best as possible. The idea of ​​functionalism was crystallized by the American architect Louis Sullivan already in 1896 by stating that "the purpose dictates the form". Later, Le Corbusier called the residential house "a machine in which to live". Scarlet and purple corundums are also counted as sapphires, because their value would be lower as rubies. The most valued color is blue, which is caused by small concentrations of iron and titanium, purple is caused by vanadium. Yellow and green are due to iron and red to chromium. Sapphire processing includes chamfering, circular grinding and gems. Sapphire is refined by heating, irradiation and diffuse coloring. The name of the stone comes from the Greek word 'sappheiros', 'blue'. passage_en: Cirrhosis is irreversible liver damage, advanced liver fibrosis, usually caused by excessive alcohol consumption or hepatitis. Although cirrhosis is incurable, its progression can be slowed in the early stages or it can be stopped completely. Sometimes cirrhosis requires a liver transplant. The disease is asymptomatic in the early stages (with the exception of the yellowing eyes of a drunkard) and later causes chronic fatigue and yellowing of the skin in the final stages. Liver transplantation is risky for older cirrhotic patients (over 65 years of age) and is therefore usually not performed in the scope of public medical care. In private hospitals, it is an expensive procedure that requires a long waiting time. For cultural reasons, cirrhosis is primarily a men's disease. However, women seem to be more prone to cirrhosis than men. Age and overweight are risk factors that worsen the disease. People die from cirrhosis in Finland every year

passage_en: Westwood Studios was a video game development company founded by Brett Sperry and Louis Castle in . The company developed, among others, the popular "Command & Conquer" games and is a pioneer of real-time strategy games. The company's early well-known games were games based on the "BattleTech" series. Other well-known ones were the "Eye of the Beholder" series of games published by Strategic Simulations. passage_en: The National Library and Archives of Bhutan (, NLAB) is a government agency operating in Thimphu, the capital of Bhutan, performing the duties of the National Library and Archives of the Kingdom. It operates under the Ministry of Home Affairs and Culture () of Bhutan. Dorji Norbu has been in charge of the National Library and Archives since 2016. passage_en: Emily Jane Brontë (30 July 1818 – 19 December 1848) was an English novelist and poet. She was one of the so-called Brontë literary sisters. Her sisters were Charlotte and Anne Brontë. Brontë's first novel was "The Humming Ridge", published in 1847. It remained his only novel, but it was enough to put his name in the history of world literature. During her lifetime, Brontë also published a collection of poems, "Poems by Currer, Ellis, and Acton Bell", which included poems by both herself and her sisters. Brontë died of tuberculosis in December 1848 at only 30 years old. Emily Brontë was born on July 30, 1818, in Thornton, Yorkshire, where her father, Patrick Brontë, was a clergyman. passage_en: Japanese mythology refers to the deities, legends and beliefs of the ancient Japanese people. The oldest and most important book about Japanese mythology is "Kojiki", which has been collecting Japanese folk tales for centuries. Another significant work containing Japanese beliefs is "Nihonshoki". After Buddhism, Confucianism and Taoism spread to Japan, the deity lost most of its meaning. However, Shintoism contains several influences inherited from it; among others, Shinto gods were originally worshiped in Japanese mythology. One of the most significant beliefs of the Japanese pantheon was the ancient myth that the Japanese imperial family was descended from the sun goddess Amaterasu. It wasn't until 1945 that Emperor Hirohito, at the insistence of the Allies, had to admit that he was not of divine descent. passage_en: Magnetic sense is the ability of several animal species to orient themselves using the Earth's magnetic field. Many migratory birds, molluscs and amphibians use the magnetic sense in their movement. For marine animals such as crawfish, sea turtles and salmon, the magnetic sense is useful because there are almost no visual direction markers below the surface. Even some mammals, such as bald rats and some species of bats, have a magnetic sense. The magnetic sense has only been verified in studies in the last few decades. In a typical experimental setup, a magnet is attached to the animal. If the animal's movement is then disturbed, it probably has some kind of magnetic sense. Animals have also been able to be controlled by changing the artificial magnetic field. However, researchers still cannot explain how the magnetic sense works, and no special sensory organ has been found in animals. Migratory birds' magnetic sense was thought to be based on iron oxide, magnetite, in their beaks.

Nagalandin pääkaupunki on Kohima. Nagalandin virallinen kieli on englanti. Suurin osa osavaltiosta on vuoristoa, jota halkovat joet. passage_en: Nagaland is a state in the northeastern part of India. Its area is 16,579 km². In 2011, its population is 1,978,502. Most of the inhabitants are Christians. The capital of Nagaland is Kohima. The official language of Nagaland is English. Most of the state is mountainous, criss-crossed by rivers. It has a monsoon climate with a dry season and a rainy season. Annual rainfall varies between 1,800 and 2,500 millimeters. Administratively, Nagaland is divided into 11 districts. Nagaland's neighboring states are Manipur to the south, Assam to the west and north, and Arunachal Pradesh to the northeast. To the east, Nagaland's border neighbor is the state of Myanmar.

query_translated_en: When did Bernard Montgomery become Marshal? [
passage_in_language: Bernard Law Montgomery (Montgomery, Alameinin 1. varakreivi, "Monty") (17. marraskuuta 1887 Lontoo – 24. maaliskuuta 1976 Alton, Hampshire) oli brittiläinen sotamarsalkka, joka tunnetaan parhaiten osallistumisestaan toisen maailmansodan merkittäviin taisteluihin liittoutuneiden puolella. Montgomery syntyi Lontoossa 1887. Opiskeltuaan St. Paulin koulussa ja Sandhurstin kuninkaallisessa sotilasakatemiassa hän liittyi vänrikin arvoisena upseerina Kuninkaallisen Warwickshiren rykmentin 1. pataljoonaan vuonna 1908 palvellen aluksi Intiassa. Ylennys luutnantiksi seurasi vuonna 1910. Ensimmäinen maailmansota alkoi elokuussa 1914, jolloin hän siirtyi rykmenttinsä mukana Ranskaan, jossa osallistui Monsin vetäytymistaisteluihin. Hän haavoittui vaikeasti Ypresissä 13. lokakuuta 1914 osallistuessaan hyökkäykseen saksalaisten hallussaan pitämään Méterenin kylään, jossa Montgomery sai tarkka-ampujan luodin oikean keuhkonsa läpi
passage_en: Bernard Law Montgomery (Montgomery, 1st Viscount Alamein, "Monty") (17 November 1887 London – 24 March 1976 Alton, Hampshire) was a British field marshal best known for taking part in major battles of the Second World War on the Allied side. Montgomery was born in London in 1887. After studying at St. Paul's School and the Royal Military Academy, Sandhurst, he joined the 1st Battalion of the Royal Warwickshire Regiment as a second lieutenant in 1908, initially serving in India. A promotion to lieutenant followed in 1910. The First World War began in August 1914, when he moved with his regiment to France, where he participated in the withdrawal battles of Mons. He was severely wounded at Ypres on 13 October 1914, taking part in an attack on the German-held village of Méteren, where Montgomery received a sniper's bullet through his right lung

passage_in_language: New Technology File System (lyhenne NTFS) on Microsoftin suunnittelema tiedostojärjestelmä, joka julkaistiin vuonna 1993 yhdessä Windows NT 3.1:n kanssa. NTFS sisältää useita parannuksia FATiin verrattuna, kuten - tuki erittäin suurille tiedostoille (jopa 2 tavua), pääsynhallintaluettelo (jolla käyttäjät voivat asettaa käyttöoikeuksia yksittäisten tiedostojen tasolla), kirjaaminen, pakkaus
passage_en: New Technology File System (abbreviation NTFS) is a file system designed by Microsoft, which was released in 1993, along with Windows NT 3.1. NTFS evolved from the HPFS file system that was designed as part of the OS/2 project shared by IBM and Microsoft and based on the principles of the Files-11 file management system, which was designed for DEC's PDP-11 computers and was also used by the VMS operating system of VAX computers. NTFS was designed to replace the FAT file system and introduced many improvements to it. NTFS includes a variety of improvements over FAT, such as - support for extremely large files (up to 2 bytes), an access control list (which allows users to set access rights at the level of individual files), journaling, compression

passage_en: The flag of the Netherlands, or prince's flag, is the emblem of the Netherlands, along with the coat of arms, motto and national anthem. It was introduced in 1579 after the Protestant provinces defeated the rebellion led by William I of Orange, Count of Nassau, against Spanish rule. The colors of the Dutch tricolor were initially orange, white and blue in accordance with the colors of William's ruling family. The orange later changed to red. The size ratio of the ticket is 2:3. The flag of the Netherlands and the flag of Luxembourg are similar except that the flag of Luxembourg is longer and its blue stripe is lighter.

passage_en: Francis of Assisi, "God's Little Poor", ("Poverello", real name Giovanni Francesco di Bernardone) (1181 or 1182 – 3 October 1226) founded the Franciscan Order. Francis is revered in Catholicism, Old Catholicism, Anglicanism and Lutheranism. Pope Gregory IX declared him a saint on July 16, 1228. According to Francis of Assisi's calendar of saints, the commemoration day is October 4, which was later also taken as international animal day for him. He is the patron saint of animals, the environment, zoos, fire, families, dying alone, merchants, peace, Italy, Assisi, New Mexico, and Kansas. Finland switched to the euro along with eleven other European Union countries on January 1, 2002; The exchange period from mark to euro lasted from January and February 2002. Marks could be redeemed for euros exactly ten years after the end of the exchange period. The official conversion factor for the euro was 5.94573 Finnish marks. Gabe Newell ja Mike Harrington perustivat Valve Corporationin (silloinen Valve Software) Kirklandissa, Washingtonissa vuonna 1996. Valven teki kuuluisaksi sen ensimmäinen julkaisu, "Half-Life," vuonna 1998. "Half-Lifen" menestyksen jälkeen Valve ryhtyi kehittämään "Team Fortress Classic" -modia "Half-Lifeen". Valve auttoi myös itsenäisiä modien kehittäjiä ja on hankkinut joidenkin modien oikeudet itselleen. Vuoden 2003 E3-messuilla Valve herätti huomiota esittelemällä materiaalia "Half-Life 2:sta", joka näytti olevan jo valmis. "Half-Life 2":n piti ilmestyä vuoden 2003 syksyllä.
passage_en: Valve Corporation (formerly Valve Software) is a Bellevue, Washington-based video game development and digital distribution company. Gabe Newell and Mike Harrington founded Valve Corporation (then Valve Software) in Kirkland, Washington in 1996. Valve was made famous by its first release, "Half-Life," in 1998. After the success of "Half-Life," Valve moved on to develop "Team Fortress Classic" -mod for "Half-Life". Valve also helped independent mod developers and has acquired the rights to some mods for themselves. Formerly independent mods owned by Valve today include "Counter-Strike" and "Day of Defeat". At E3 2003, Valve attracted attention by showing footage of "Half-Life 2" that appeared to be already completed. "Half-Life 2" was supposed to be released in the fall of 2003.

passage_en: Space exploration is the study of the solar system and the universe around it with instruments outside the Earth. Space is explored with, among other things, space telescopes, satellites orbiting the Earth, and robotic probes sent into outer space. The space age began in 1957 when the Soviet satellite Sputnik 1 sent a radio signal to Earth. It was soon followed by the Soviet Union's Luna program and the United States' Pioneer and Ranger programs. These probes passed close to the Moon or crashed into its surface. At the beginning of the 1960s, planetary flights to Venus and Mars began. In 1973, the US spacecraft Mariner 10 passed Venus and continued on to Mercury. The Soviet Union's Venera 9 and 10 probes took pictures of the surface of Venus, and later the Pioneer Venus and Magellan probes used radar to map its surface. passage_in_language: Abbasidikalifaatti (, "") oli kolmas Islamilainen kalifaatti. Sen perusti Muhammedin sedän Abbas ibn Abdul-Muttalibin (566-653) – jonka mukaan kalifaatti on nimetty – perillinen. Abbasidit hallitsivat suurinta osaa kalifaattia pääkaupungistaan Bagdadista käsin kalifeina kaadettuaan Umaijadien kalifaatin vuonna 750 päättyneessä Abbasidien vallankumouksessa. Abbasidien ajanjaksoa leimasi riippuvuus Persian byrokraattien (erityisesti Barmakid-suvun) hallitsemista alueista sekä arabimaiden ulkopuolisten muslimien lisääntyvä määrä "ummassa" (islamin uskovien yhteisö). Hallitseva eliitti omaksui laajasti persialaiset tavat ja he alkoivatkin tukemaan taiteilijoita ja oppineita. Bagdadista tuli tieteen, kulttuurin, filosofian ja keksintöjen keskus. Nykyään
passage_en: The Abbasid Caliphate (, "") was the third Islamic Caliphate. It was founded by the heir of Muhammad's uncle Abbas ibn Abdul-Muttalib (566-653) – after whom the caliphate is named. The Abbasids ruled most of the caliphate from their capital, Baghdad, as caliphs after overthrowing the Umayyad Caliphate in the Abbasid Revolution that ended in 750. The administration of the Abbasid Caliphate was initially centered in Kufa, but in 762 Caliph Al-Mansur founded the city of Baghdad near the ancient Sasanian capital of Ctesiphon. The Abbasid period was marked by dependence on territories controlled by Persian bureaucrats (especially the Barmakid clan) and the increasing number of non-Arab Muslims in the "umma" (community of believers in Islam). The ruling elite widely adopted Persian customs and began to support artists and scholars. Baghdad became a center of science, culture, philosophy and invention. Today

passage_en: Hadera () is a city in Israel in the Haifa District. The current city was founded by Jewish immigrants in 1890. At the end of 2016, the city had a population of 91,707. The current name of Hadera is derived from the Arabic name "al-Khaḍrāʾ" meaning green, which referred to the area's marshes and the algae that grew there. The earliest signs of settlement in the Hadera area come from the Chalcolithic period. Many Bronze Age discoveries have been made in the area, such as buildings, mosaics and, for example, a Roman bridge. The Crusaders called the city there Lictera, but the place was abandoned after the Crusades. The current Hadera was founded in 1890 by members of Hovevei Zion, immigrants from Vilna, Kovno and Riga. passage_en: Pekka Sakari Silvola (November 26, 1924 Kiikoinen – June 22, 2015 Espoo) was a political influencer who held various positions in the Maalaisliitto/Centre party, including as party secretary 1960–1969. In 1970, Silvola was appointed program director of Yleisradio, from which position he retired in 1985. Pekka Silvola was born into a farming family from Satakunta. Among the parents, the father was involved in the Pellervola, or SOK, cooperative store, as well as the protection council and the Maalaisliito. Of the family's children, Iika became a reverend and vicar of Jämijärvi, Paavo became a rector, Peka became a party secretary and Yleisradio's program director. Silvola's school was interrupted in the sixth grade due to military service in 1943. On June 16, 1944, he was assigned as a squad leader to infantry regiment 7, the Tyrjä regiment, which was later led by Adolf Ehrnrooth, who was promoted to infantry general. Silvola was wounded on July 9 in Äyräpää. For sports achievements

passage_en: Groupe Renault (pronounced ɡʁup ʁəno according to the IPA) is a French automobile manufacturer. Groupe Renault owns almost half of Japanese Nissan, almost all of Russian AvtoVAZ, a quarter of Japanese Mitsubishi Motors, and all of French Alpine, Romanian Dacia and Korean Renault Samsung Motors. passage_en: Androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS), i.e. male hormone insensitivity syndrome, is a rare intersex, X-chromosomally recessively inherited and polymorphic syndrome, in which the cells of a person who is genetically male, i.e. a person with XY sex chromosomes, react only partially or not at all to the male hormones produced by their own body. This disrupts or completely prevents the development of male characteristics and male genitalia from the fetal stage in a person with AIS. Almost all AI syndromes have a mutation in the androgen receptor that weakens or completely prevents its ability to respond to male hormones, but the syndrome can rarely be caused by other factors as well. The severity of AIS symptoms in a person with XY chromosomes varies, but they are known not to affect the person's lifespan. passage_en: An earthquake is a vibration of the Earth's bedrock, which, when strong, is very destructive to buildings and people. A weak earthquake shakes lamps, a strong earthquake collapses houses, a very strong one shakes the soil. An earthquake at the bottom of the sea can cause a strong tidal wave, a tsunami. The underground location of an earthquake is the hypocenter, and the surface center is the epicenter. Earthquake waves, or seismic waves, are divided into longitudinal and transverse waves and surface waves. By studying the reflections and refractions of earthquake waves, the structure of the bedrock and the entire Earth can be determined to some extent. Earthquakes can be detected from afar with a device called a seismometer or seismograph. The recording of an earthquake is called a seismogram. passage_in_language: Kannibalismi tarkoittaa samaa lajia olevan yksilön syömistä. Myös eläintä, joka syö oman lajinsa edustajia, kutsutaan kannibaaliksi. Ihmistä, joka syö toista ihmistä, kutsutaan nimellä ihmissyöjä eli antropofagi. Termi ”kannibaali” tulee espanjasta. Kristoffer Kolumbus oletti saapuessaan Amerikkaan, että Haitin asukkaat olisivat Kiinan suurkaanin alamaisia. Valmistautuessaan tapaamiseen hänellä oli mukanaan arabian ja heprean taitajia. Kuullessaan nimen Caniba tai Canima hän oletti sanan viittaavan Mendevillen kuvaamiin koirapäisiin ihmisiin (cane-bal). Samuel Purchas on väittänyt sanan tarkoittavan ”uljaita miehiä” karibien kielellä. Richard Hakluyt toi sanan englantiin ja Shakespeare käytti sitä näytelmässään "Myrsky" Caliban-hirviön nimenä. Kannibalismia pidetään yleisesti ruokatabuna. Sitä on kuitenkin harrastettu uskontoon ja sodankäyntiin liittyvissä
passage_en: Cannibalism means eating an individual of the same species. An animal that eats members of its own species is also called a cannibal. A person who eats another person is called a man-eater or anthropophagus. The term "cannibal" comes from Spanish. When Christopher Columbus arrived in America, he assumed that the people of Haiti would be subjects of the Great Khan of China. When preparing for the meeting, he had with him experts in Arabic and Hebrew. When he heard the name Caniba or Canima, he assumed the word referred to the dog-headed people (cane-bal) described by Mendeville. Samuel Purchas has argued that the word means "brazen men" in the Carib language. Richard Hakluyt brought the word to England and Shakespeare used it in his play "The Tempest" as the name of the monster Caliban. Cannibalism is generally considered a food taboo. However, it has been practiced in those related to religion and warfare

passage_en: Evald is a Germanic male first name of origin. It is formed from the Germanic words "e" meaning "law" and "order" and "wald" meaning "ruling". The name was popularized by two Anglo-Saxon missionaries who lived at the end of the 7th century, the so-called White and Black Evald, who operated in Germany in the Rhine region and were martyred there. Their memorial day is October 3, which is also Evald's name day according to the Finnish-Swedish calendar. In Finland, the name Evald was given to 2,074 people from the beginning of the 20th century until the end of 2009, and Ewald to 60 people, according to the data of the Population Register Center.

passage_en: The ship Argo (also Argo, ) is an old constellation that Ptolemy named in his group of 48 constellations. Its prototype is the Argo of Greek mythology, which was the ship used by Jason and the Argonauts. Argo is not among the 88 constellations in use today, as in 1763 the French astronomer Nicolas Louis de Lacaille split it into Köl ("Carina"), Stern ("Puppis") and Sail ("Vela"). While Argo was broken up, its stars were divided into different constellations: Argo's α and β stars remained in the Köl, γ and δ in the Sail, ε in the Köl, and ζ in the Bow. passage_en: Peter Steele (real name Petrus Thomas Ratajczyk, January 4, 1962 – April 14, 2010) was the lead singer, bassist and songwriter of the American heavy metal band Type O Negative. Steele is remembered for his gothic appearance, his impressively large height, his low singing voice and his peculiar, dry humor and original approach to playing the bass. The lyrics he writes often deal with his own life, such as love, loss and addiction. Steele cited Black Sabbath and the Beatles as his biggest musical influences. passage_en: Psychedelics are compounds that cause altered states of consciousness such as hallucinations, mystical experiences, hallucinations, strong emotional states and the surfacing of memories. They act like neurotransmitters and activate receptors on the surface of nerve cells. The most well-known psychedelics are, for example, LSD, psilocin, mescaline, LSA and DMT. The use of most psychedelics is prohibited in much of the world, except for licensed use in religious ceremonies, therapy or scientific research, for example. In medicine, psychedelics have been used, for example, as a treatment for addictions. Psychedelics are often defined pharmacologically as part of a wider group of hallucinogens, which also includes dissociatives and deliriums. The term "psychedelic" was coined in 1956 by psychedelic researcher Humphry Osmond. He combined the Greek words "psyche", "soul, mind" and "delein", "express".

passage_en: Dendrology (from the Greek words "dendron" 'tree' and "logos" 'teaching'), i.e. tree science, means the study of woody plants. Dendrology defines, describes and classifies woody plants and studies their biological properties. Plants with woody stems are, for example, trees, shrubs, ferns and lianas. They do not form a taxonomically coherent group, and therefore are not necessarily closely related to each other. Many plant genera have both woody and herbaceous species, and many include only a few woody species.

There is some variation in the classification of moraine species, but most commonly the division is made according to the most abundant variety; we are talking about gravel, sand or silt moraine, depending on which type is the most dominant in the moraine. It met on January 25, 1919 and recommended action against citizens of enemy countries accused of war crimes. The commission issued a report stating that all enemies who violated the laws and customs of war or the laws of humanity should be prosecuted, regardless of command or rank. For this, a special high court had to be established, which would investigate and judge cases according to international law. passage_en: Damn Seagulls is a Finnish rock, soul and punk band founded in 1997 in Helsinki. Singer and songwriter Lauri Eloranta is known as its frontman. Eloranta's influences include the early productions of Bruce Springsteen and the manic-depressive soul rock of The Afghan Whigs. Shiva is depicted in many figures, but is often worshiped in an abstract form: the object of worship is the "linga", a phallic symbol represented by a stone slab, standing on top of the "yoni", the feminine principle (or power). The most important symbol of Shiva is the trident, which represents the three levels of being and the trinity gods Brahma, Vishnu and Rudra (which is often, somewhat misleadingly, also identified directly with Shiva). passage_en: The Aegean Sea or "Aegean Sea" (, ) is an island part of the Mediterranean Sea located between the Balkan Peninsula and Asia Minor. It is connected to the Black Sea via the Dardanelles, the Sea of ​​Marmara and the Bosphorus. The Aegean islands belong to Greece, with a few exceptions. The sea is Greece's most significant sea area, along with the Ionian Sea. In antiquity, there were several explanations for the name Aegean. It was said to have been named after the city of Aigai, known as a cult place for Poseidon, Aigea, queen of the Amazons, or Aigeus, father of Theseus, who drowned himself in the sea thinking his son was dead. The etymology of the name can also be based on the word "aiges" (αἶγες, 'waves'), in which case it could mean "Wavy sea". The area of ​​the Aegean Sea is approximately 215,000 square kilometers. Antestor on Norjan varhaisimpia kristillisesti vakaumuksellisia extreme metal -ryhmiä, ja yhtyeen sanotaan aloittaneen koko Pohjois-Euroopan kristilliset extreme metal -piirit demollaan "The Defeat of Satan" 1991. Aiemmin yhtye kutsui musiikkityyliänsä "sorrow metaliksi" (), koska sen kristillinen ideologia ei sopinut black metaliin, joka erityisesti Norjassa oli usein julkisestikin liitetty saatananpalvontaan. Antestor tunnetaan yleisesti siitä, että se on ainoa kristillinen black metal -yhtye, jolla on ollut levytyssopimus brittiläisen Cacophonous Recordsin kanssa – yhden suurimmista black metaliin erikoistuneista levy-yhtiöistä, joka on julkaissut levyjä sellaisilta yhtyeiltä kuin Cradle of Filth, Dimmu Borgir ja Sigh.
passage_en: Antestor is a Norwegian extreme metal band formed in Jessheim in 1990. Antestor is one of Norway's earliest Christian extreme metal bands, and is said to have started the Christian extreme metal circuit throughout Northern Europe with their demo "The Defeat of Satan" in 1991. Previously, the band called its music style as "sorrow metal" (), because its Christian ideology did not fit black metal, which, especially in Norway, was often publicly associated with Satan worship. Antestor is widely known for being the only Christian black metal band to have a record deal with the UK's Cacophonous Records - one of the major black metal labels that have released albums by bands such as Cradle of Filth, Dimmu Borgir and Sigh.

Konstantin Tsiolkovsky presented the principle of the space elevator in an article he wrote in 1895. The theory was developed by Yuri Artsutanov in an article he wrote in 1960. The space elevator has traditionally appeared mostly in science fiction, such as Arthur C. Clarke's "Fountains of Paradise", but with the development of technology, it has been studied more seriously. The space elevator would have to be located approximately on the equator and its top part orbiting the Earth would have to rotate around the planet at the same angular speed as the planet rotates, otherwise the shaft would break as the top moves away from the base. One operational possibility of a space elevator would be to lift satellites and other ships into orbit around the Earth, and connect it with a cable to the ground. query_translated_en: Where was the Abbasid Caliphate founded?
passage_in_language: Fatimidit tai fatimidien kalifaatti oli šiiamuslimien dynastia, joka hallitsi suurta osaa Pohjois-Afrikasta vuodesta 910 vuoteen 1171. Fatimidit kuuluivat nykyisin šiialaisten vähemmistöä edustavaan ismailiittien suuntaukseen. Dynastian vuonna 909 perustanut, Pohjois-Afrikkaan siirtynyt Ubayd Allah al-Mahdi Billah esitti olevansa ismailiittien kätkeytyneen imaamin, Ismail bin Jafarin perillinen ja vaati valtaa koko muslimimaailmassa. Hän sai pian haltuunsa koko Keski-Maghrebin, johon kuuluivat nykyiset Marokko, Algeria, Tunisia ja Libya. Sitä hallittiin Tunisiaan perustetusta pääkaupungista käsin. Fatimidit valloittivat Egyptin 972, siirsivät pääkaupunkinsa Kairoon ja haastoivat vakavasti sunnalaisen abbasidien kalifaatin. Fatimidien hallitseman alueen väestö ei laajassa mitassa kääntynyt ismailiiteiksi, vaan pysyi enimmäkseen sunnalaisina. Egyptissä oli myös merkittävä kristitty väestö.
passage_en: The Fatimids, or the Fatimid Caliphate, were a Shiite Muslim dynasty that ruled much of North Africa from 910 to 1171. The Fatimids belonged to the Ismaili sect, which today represents a minority of Shiites. Ubayd Allah al-Mahdi Billah, who founded the dynasty in 909 and moved to North Africa, presented himself as the heir of the hidden Ismaili imam, Ismail bin Jafar, and claimed power in the entire Muslim world. He soon gained control of the entire Central Maghreb, which included present-day Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia and Libya. It was governed from the capital established in Tunisia. The Fatimids conquered Egypt in 972, moved their capital to Cairo, and seriously challenged the Sunni Abbasid Caliphate. The population of the area ruled by the Fatimids did not convert to Ismaili to a large extent, but remained mostly Sunni. Egypt also had a significant Christian population.

passage_en: Uusikaupunki (, originally "Kalainen") is a coastal city in Finland. It belongs to the province of Varsinais-Suomi and the region of Vakka-Suomi. Uusikaupunki is the main center of its district. The city is known for, among other things, the car factory and the wooden house center based on the grid pattern. King Gustav II Adolf founded the city in 1617, so Uusikaupunki is the 12th oldest city in Finland. Uusilakaupunki also has a part in European history, as the peace of the Great Northern War was declared there in 1721. The city flourished especially in the 19th century, when the shipbuilding period was lived. In addition to the center of Uusikaupunki, the city includes the former municipalities of Uusikaupunki rural district, Kalanti, Lokalahti and Pyhämaa. The neighboring municipalities are Kustavi, Laitila, Pyhäranta, Taivassalo and Vehmaa. Uusikaupunki is located in Varsinais-Suomi province, Vakka-Suomi region. The city is located on the shore of the Gulf of Pohjan, 70 kilometers northwest of Turku.

Kilpailut järjestettiin ensimmäisen kerran 1893 ja on pidetty sen jälkeen vuosittain lukuun ottamatta sotavuosia 1915–1919 ja 1940–1945. Järjestäjämaan pyöräilyliitto järjestää kilpailut kansainvälisen pyöräilyliiton valvonnassa. Chicagossa järjestetyt ensimmäiset MM-kilpailut oli tarkoitettu ainoastaan amatööreille. Vuoden 1895 kisoissa Kööpenhaminassa oli ensimmäisen kerran lajeja myös ammattilaisille. Erillisiä ammattilaisten ja amatöörien MM-titteleitä jaettiin vuoden 1992 kisoihin saakka, jonka jälkeen on kilpailtu kaikille avoimissa luokissa. MM-kilpailujen ohjelmassa on tällä hetkellä (2010) kaikkiaan 19 lajia. Sekä miesten että naisten lajeina ovat aika-ajo, keirin, henkilökohtainen takaa-ajo, joukkuetakaa-ajo, pisteajo, linja-ajo, eräajo, joukkuesprintti ja omnium. Miesten ohjelmassa on lisäksi pariajo.
passage_en: The track cycling world championships are the most important track cycling competitions together with track cycling at the Olympics. The competitions were organized for the first time in 1893 and have been held every year since then, except for the war years 1915–1919 and 1940–1945. The organizing country's cycling association organizes the competitions under the supervision of the International Cycling Federation. The first World Championships organized in Chicago were intended only for amateurs. At the 1895 Games in Copenhagen, there were also sports for professionals for the first time. Separate World Championship titles for professionals and amateurs were awarded until the 1992 Games, after which competition has been held in categories open to all. There are currently (2010) a total of 19 sports in the program of the World Championships. The sports for both men and women are time trial, keirin, individual pursuit, team pursuit, points race, line race, heat race, team sprint and omnium. The men's program also includes a pair race.

passage_en: The AIS classification () is a severity classification developed in the United States, especially for the classification of injuries caused in traffic accidents. In the AIS code, the first six digits indicate the location and type of injury, and the number after the dot indicates the severity of the injury. For example, the number series 441438.5 means unilateral contusion of the lung with tension pneumothorax, and the injury is classified as critical in severity.

Lisäksi sen aikana uhrattiin veretön uhri Eirenelle eli rauhan henkilöitymälle. Thukydides ja Plutarkhos mainitsevat juhlan, eli se oli olemassa vielä heidän aikanaan. passage_en: The Synoikia (, also ) () was a festival in ancient Athens dedicated to Athena. It was then that Theseus' unification of the villages of Attica () into the city of Athens was remembered. The festival was celebrated on the 16th of the month of Hekatombaion, i.e. around the current July-August. According to Athenian tradition, the festival was founded by Theseus himself. It was dedicated to Athena as the protector of Athens and all of united Attica. The celebration also honored Zeus Fratrio. In addition, during that time, a bloodless sacrifice was offered to Eirene, the personification of peace. Thucydides and Plutarch mention the festival, meaning it still existed in their time. Plutarch called it "Metoikia" (). According to one interpretation, the celebration would have been one-day every other year and two-day every other year (Hekatombaion 15-16).

passage_en: William Pitt (28 May 1759 – 23 January 1806) was a British statesman, Prime Minister 1783–1801 and 1804–1806. William Pitt was the second eldest son of William Pitt, Earl of Chatham, who was British Prime Minister from 1766 to 1768. Pitt rose to Parliament in 1781; he became Minister of Finance in 1782 and Prime Minister in 1783 at the age of only 24. Pitt's prime ministership coincided with the reign of King George III and coincided with the French Revolution and the Napoleonic Wars. His reputation rests on his reforms in the 1780s, with which he was able to restore the economy and honor of the country after the American Revolution. passage_en: Thrasyllos (; 406 BC) was a strategos (general) and statesman who rose to prominence in the years following the Peloponnesian War. First appearing in Athenian politics in 410 BC, after the Athenian coup in 411 BC, he played a role in organizing democratic resistance in the Athenian fleet on Samos. There, he was elected strategos by the sailors and soldiers of the fleet, and held that position until he was controversially executed several years later after the Battle of Arginousai. Thrasyllus was only a hoplite (heavy infantry) in the ranks in 410 BC, when the Athenian oligarchic revolutionaries conspired with their counterparts in Samos in a coup.

passage_en: A housing price bubble is a situation where the price of housing differs from the equilibrium price determined by the fundamentals of the market. In a market economy, the law of supply and demand, through people's actions, brings housing prices to the level that people are willing to pay. When prices deviate from this, we talk about a housing price bubble. In connection with price bubbles in the economy, John Maynard Keynes' description of the stock market from 1936 is often referred to, where, according to Keynes, speculators "try to predict the development of public opinion", instead of paying attention to the "fundamentals of the functioning of the market". In this case, price changes caused by the self-fulfilling expectations of economic operators arise. The change can cause a rising price bubble, which, when it bursts, causes a drop in prices and possibly a bubble in the opposite direction, underpricing. Keynes has not been accepted by most members of mainstream economics

passage_en: Alain de Benoist, born December 11, 1943, is a French academic, philosopher, writer, journalist and founder of the ethno-nationalist think tank GRECE ("Groupement de recherche et d'études pour la civilization européenne", or "Society for Research and Study of the European civilization") and prominent figure within the French New Right. Benoist studied law, political science, philosophy and history of religion at the Sorbonne. He has subsequently been editor of the two newspapers "Nouvelle École", "Éléments" and "Krisis". His writings have also been published in several other newspapers, including some of France's leading ones, such as Le Figaro and Le Monde. query_translated_en: What is the main religion of Japan?
passage_in_language: Hana matsuri ( tai ) on japanilainen kukkajuhla, jolla juhlistetaan Buddhan syntymäpäivää. Juhlaa vietetään 8. huhtikuuta eikä se ole kansallinen pyhäpäivä. Päivää vietetään temppeleissä kaatamalla pienellä kauhalla kukilla koristellulla alttarilla olevan Buddhan patsaan päälle päälle makeaa teetä tai amachaa. Juhlan luonne vaihtelee paikasta toiseen. "Kanbutsu-e" sekä "hana matsuri" sekoittuivat toisiinsa Meiji-kaudella, josta lähtien Buddhan syntymäpäivä on tunnettu hana matsurina. Kerrotaan, että kun Buddha syntyi, yhdestä yhdeksään lohikäärmettä kaatoi hänen päällensä puhdasta, hyvätuoksuista vettä. Toinen, alkuperäiseen hana matsuriin liittyvä uskomus on, että keväällä jumala laskeutui alas vuorilta suojelemaan riisipeltoja ja syksyllä nousi vuorille suojelemaan niitä. Hana matsuria vietettiin jumalan toivottamiseksi tervetulleeksi.
passage_en: Hana matsuri ( tai ) is a Japanese flower festival celebrating Buddha's birthday. The celebration is celebrated on April 8 and is not a national holiday. The day is spent in temples pouring sweet tea or amacha over the Buddha statue on the altar decorated with flowers with a small ladle. The nature of the celebration varies from place to place. "Kanbutsu-e" and "hana matsuri" were mixed together in the Meiji period, and since then Buddha's birthday has been known as hana matsuri. It is said that when the Buddha was born, one to nine dragons poured pure, fragrant water over him. Another belief related to the original hana matsuri is that in the spring the god came down from the mountains to protect the rice fields and in the fall he ascended the mountains to protect them. Hana matsuri was celebrated to welcome the god.

He founded the Jamaat-e-Islami party in 1941 and was its leader until 1972. Maududi advocated the transformation of Islamic Pakistan into one governed by Sharia as interpreted by Shura courts. His most influential work was "Risalat Diniyat". Maududi's ideas influenced the Muslim Brotherhood, which was founded as a critique of liberal Islam in Egypt at the beginning of the 20th century. The Muslim Brotherhood's motto was "The Koran is our constitution." Said Qutb, an Egyptian member of the Muslim Brotherhood, was a particularly important background influence for radical Islamism and jihadism. passage_in_language: Magneetto on usein mopoista, moottorikelkoista ja -pyöristä tuttu sähkögeneraattori, joka tuottaa sytytysvirran sekä mahdollisen akun latausvirran ja valojen tarvitseman virran. Magneetto toimii myös lähes poikkeuksetta moottorin vauhtipyöränä, joka mahdollistaa moottorin tasaisen ja vääntöä tuottavan käynnin. Vanhemmassa kalustossa magneetto on yleensä erillinen laite ja se toimii lähes yksinomaan sytytyskoneena ts. ei tuota virtaa muille laitteille. Erillistä magneettoa käytti pisimpään luultavasti Harley Davidson. Erillisiä magneettoja on maa- ja venekeskimoottoreissa (Olympia, Wickström, Kipinä, Vire jne.). Erillisiä magneettoja valmisti mm. Bosch ja Suomessa Mars Magneto (1920-luvulla). Sähkötekniikan historiassa magneetolla on tarkoitettu sähkömoottorin kanssa samalla akselilla olevaa apugenerattoria magnetointivirran synnyttämiseen tai voimistamiseen.
passage_en: The magneto is an electric generator often known from mopeds, snowmobiles and bicycles, which produces the ignition current as well as the possible battery charging current and the current needed by the lights. The magneto almost always acts as the engine's flywheel, which enables the engine to run smoothly and produce torque. In older vehicles, the magneto is usually a separate device and it works almost exclusively as an ignition machine, i.e. it does not generate power for other devices. A separate magnet was probably used by Harley Davidson for the longest time. There are separate magnets in land and boat mid-engines (Olympia, Wickström, Kipinä, Vire, etc.). Separate magnets were manufactured by e.g. Bosch and in Finland Mars Magneto (in the 1920s). In the history of electrical engineering, magneto refers to an auxiliary generator on the same axis as the electric motor for generating or amplifying the magnetizing current.

passage_en: Bandiagara–Hombor highland () is a natural area in the central part of Mali. It mainly belongs to the Mopti region, extending to Timbuktu in the northeast and Ségou in the south. In the middle of the highlands are the 450-800 meter high Dogon Plateau and the Gandamia and Hombo mountains. To the south is the Bobo plateau and to the north is the Dyoundé-Erensis region. The Dogon, or Bandiagara, plateau borders on the 300–600 meter high, 200 km long Bandiagara rock slope, with the Gondo-Séno plateau on the east side. In the west, the highlands descend gently into the floodplain of the Niger inland delta. The Gandami mountains near Douentza rise to a height of 500-600 meters. The highest place in Mali is Homborivuori, 1155 meters high, rising above the Gourma plateau. Ylänkö is located in the catchment area of ​​the Niger tributary Yamé. passage_en: In mathematics, a topos (, ; plural topoi or , or toposes) is a category that behaves like the category of sheaves of sets on a topological space (or more generally: on a site). Topoi behave much like the category of sets and possess a notion of localization; they are in a sense a generalization of point-set topology. The Grothendieck topoi find applications in algebraic geometry; the more general elementary topoi are used in logic. Since the introduction of sheaves into mathematics in the 1940s, a major theme has been to study a space by studying sheaves on a space.

For example, all different conic sections are equivalent in complex projective geometry, and some theorems about circles can be conceived as special cases of these general theorems. At the beginning of the 19th century, the researches of, among others, Jean-Victor Poncelet and Lazare Carnot made projective geometry an independent branch of mathematics. Its foundations were refined by Karl von Staudt, and at the end of the 19th century the Italians Giuseppe Peano, Mario Pieri, Alessandro Padoa and Gino Fano developed them into a perfect form. Like affine and Euclidean geometry, projective geometry can also be formulated using Felix Klein's Erlangen program: projective geometry is characterized by the invariants of transformations of the projective group. The basics of projective geometry became understood when a great many theorems had been derived from the field with the help of extensive research.

passage_en: Aisha bint Abu Bakr (, "she who lives", other spellings A'ishah, Ayesha, A'isha and Aisha, 613 or 614 Mecca – July 678 Medina) was the third wife of the Islamic prophet Muhammad. She is sometimes called Muhammad's favorite wife. In Islamic writings, she is often referred to by the title "Mother of the Believers" (), according to the description in the Qur'an (33:6), where Muhammad's wives are called "mothers of the believers". Many hadiths, or traditions about the life of the Prophet Muhammad, are written in Aisha's name. Aisha's father Abu Bakr was one of Muhammad's most important supporters even before Aisha's union with Muhammad. When such a formation contains a lot of sorted ridge material, it is called an edge formation. For example, Salpausellä are edge formations. The glacier detaches the moraine from the rock and carries it with it. When the marginal moraine was formed, the glacier has remained in place and it has been a rather cold season. Among other things, Diocletian reformed taxation and tried to stop the depreciation of money. He reformed the army, and the security of the country increased so that the Roman Empire was not threatened by barbarian invasions or internal rebellions. Diocletian renewed the supreme power of Rome by establishing the tetrarchy, where four emperors divided the empire among themselves. passage_en: DDR2 SDRAM (Double Data Rate Synchronous Dynamic Random Access Memory, second generation) is a type of main memory used in computing as both RAM and video memory. Like DDR SDRAM, DDR2 SDRAM uses both rising and falling clock data transfer, which means that at the same memory bus frequency as in conventional SDRAM, you can actually double the speed.

passage_en: General John Churchill, 1st Duke of Marlborough, Prince of Mindelheim, KG, PC (26 May 1650 – 16 June 1722) was an English military commander and statesman who served under a total of five different monarchs. He began as a lowly paas in the court of the Stuart family and served James, Duke of York in the 1670s and early 1680s, earning military and political promotions for his bravery and diplomatic skills. Churchill's role in putting down the Monmouth Rebellion in 1685 helped secure James's accession to the throne, but just three years later he abandoned his Catholic favorite for the Protestant Dutch William of Orange. At William's coronation, he was granted the earldom of Marlborough as a tribute for his subservience. passage_in_language: Äkillinen hengitysvaikeusoireyhtymä tai aikuisen hengitysvaikeusoireyhtymä eli ARDS () tarkoittaa äkillisesti ilmaantuvaa keuhkovauriota, jonka seurauksena ilmenee vaikea happeutumishäiriö. ARDS:n aiheuttaa yleensä suoraan keuhkoja vaurioittava perussairaus, kuten keuhkokuume. Toisinaan ARDS voi syntyä epäsuorasti elimistön voimakkaan tulehdusvasteen kautta, esimerkiksi sepsiksessä, haimatulehduksessa tai keuhkojen palovammassa. ARDS:n syntymekanismina on laaja-alainen keuhkorakkuloiden ja keuhkojen hiussuonten seinämien vaurio. Oireyhtymä alkaa muutamia päiviä kestävällä eksudatiivisella vaiheella, jolloin neste tihkuu vaurioituneista verisuonista keuhkokudokseen ja aiheuttaa keuhkoturvotuksen. Sen jälkeen tapahtuu eksudaattien organisoitumista ja keuhkorakkulasolujen proliferaatiota muutaman viikon kestävässä proliferatiivisessa vaiheessa. Lopulta keuhkovaurio etenee keuhkofibroosiin eli sidekudosmuodostukseen ja keuhkojen arpeutumiseen. ARDS johtaa keuhkopöhöön, veren happeutumisen vaikeutumiseen, verenpaineen nousuun, keuhkoverenkierron vastuksen kasvamiseen
passage_en: Sudden respiratory distress syndrome or adult respiratory distress syndrome or ARDS () refers to a sudden lung injury that results in severe oxygenation disorder. ARDS is usually caused by an underlying disease that directly damages the lungs, such as pneumonia. Sometimes ARDS can arise indirectly through the body's strong inflammatory response, for example in sepsis, pancreatitis or a lung burn. The mechanism of ARDS is extensive damage to the walls of alveoli and pulmonary capillaries. The syndrome begins with an exudative phase lasting a few days, when fluid seeps from the damaged blood vessels into the lung tissue and causes pulmonary edema. After that, exudates are organized and alveolar cells proliferate in a proliferative phase lasting a few weeks. Eventually, lung damage progresses to pulmonary fibrosis, i.e. connective tissue formation and scarring of the lungs. ARDS leads to pulmonary edema, difficulty in blood oxygenation, increase in blood pressure, increase in pulmonary circulation resistance

Laulu alkaa sanoilla ”Illalla kun äiti peitti mua nukkumaan, en aavistanut mitä aamu tuopi tullessaan...”. Laulu tunnetaan erityisesti Anneli Saariston levytyksenä vuodelta 1985. Levytyksen sovittajana toimi Upi Sorvali. Koskettavasta laulusta on tullut karjalaissukuisten keskuudessa merkittävä tunteiden tulkki kansanlaulun ”Karjalan kunnailla” ohella. Aiheen lauluun antoi Laville hänen pitkäaikainen säestäjänsä Pertti Husu, joka kerran keikkamatkalla kertoi evakkotarinansa Laville. Ensimmäisenä ”Evakon laulun” esitti Porissa Veikko Tuomi, mutta tunnetuksi se tuli Anneli Saariston versiona. Laulun levytystilanteessa Saariston oli vaikea pidätellä kyyneliään.
passage_en: "Evako laulu" is a piece of music composed and written by Veikko Lavi, which tells the story of a Karelian emigrant's wartime evacuation trip to Finland from the point of view of a small child. The song begins with the words "In the evening when my mother covered me to sleep, I had no idea what the morning would bring...". The song is especially well known as a recording by Anneli Saaristo from 1985. The recording was arranged by Upi Sorvali. The touching song has become a significant interpreter of emotions among people of Karelian descent, along with the folk song "Karjalan kunnai". The theme for the song was given to Lavi by his long-time accompanist Pertti Husu, who once told Lavi his evacuee story on a concert trip. "Evako's song" was first performed by Veikko Tuomi in Pori, but it became known as Anneli Saariston's version. During the recording of the song, Saariston had a hard time holding back his tears.

Näin syntyi luokkaan kaksi alaluokkaa: Dido-luokka ja Bellona-luokka eli paranneltu Dido-luokka. Varsinaiseen Dido-luokkaan kuului yksitoista alusta. Luokan alukset oli varustettu puoliautomaattisilla 5,25 tuuman tykeillä. Voimansiirrolla varustetut asennukset mahdollistivat jopa 70 asteen korotuskulman käytön. Uusien tykkitornien hidas toimitus aiheutti alusten pääaseistuksen moninaisuuden. Alusten kylkipanssarointi oli 3-tuumainen ja kansi tuumainen konehuoneiden kohdalta. Peräsin oli suojattu samoin tuumaisella panssarilla. Ammusvarastot oli suojattu 2 tuuman kansipanssaroinnilla. Tykkitornien seinän paksuus oli 0,5 tuumaa.
passage_en: The Dido class was a class of anti-aircraft cruisers of the British Royal Navy consisting of sixteen ships, six of which were discontinued due to perceived modification needs. Of these six, however, "HMS Argonaut" was already too far built, and its modifications were cancelled. passage_en: Synoikismos (, "living together") in ancient Greece meant the establishment of a new city or polis, or city-state, by combining a number of earlier settlements into a new city and establishing a new urban center for it. The combined settlements could be villages or earlier polises that became subordinate to the new polis. Sometimes unification was a purely political measure and did not change the structure of the settlement, while sometimes it even involved population transfers. Sometimes the term "sympoliteia" has been used in the same sense.

passage_en: Geographically, Tampere has many surface formations. North of the center is Pirkanmaa's largest central lake Näsijärvi. To the south of it is Pyhäjärvi, and between them Tammerkoski, dammed through the center, flows. There are also ridge landscapes in the center, as the ridge section starting from Salpausela continues in Tampere, e.g. as Pyynik ridge. Tampere belongs to the southern boreal region of the coniferous forest zone. The most common type of forest in the area is a thicket growing from blueberries and spruce, and the most common tree in the natural forest is spruce. Pine grows abundantly where spruce does not thrive. Hardwoods also grow in the natural forest. Tampere has 11 protected areas under the Nature Conservation Act, the largest of which is the Teisko Vattula nature reserve, which is the largest in Tampere. passage_en: −0 (negative zero or minus zero) is a representation of zero used in some contexts. In the mathematical sense, the number 0 is not a positive or negative number, but in certain situations even in connection with zero, signs are used. In computer programming, in the IEEE 754 floating-point standard, a negative zero is represented by a binary number whose sign bit is one and all other bits are zero. In information technology, negative zero is sometimes used, for example, in situations where a number smaller than zero is rounded to zero, or if an arithmetic underflow occurs during a calculation. In meteorology, minus zero is used in connection with weather forecasts, when indicating temperatures close to zero, but below it. This is especially useful with the Celsius scale, because water freezes below zero and melts above zero.

passage_en: Erwin Vandenbergh (born January 26, 1959 in Ramsel, Belgium) is a Belgian former footballer, playing as a striker. In 1979, Erwin scored 39 goals in 34 matches and thus won the European Golden Boot. During his career, Vandenbergh also represented the French club Lille. passage_in_language: Melvin Robert ”Bom” Laird (1. syyskuuta 1922 Omaha, Nebraska – 16. marraskuuta 2016 Florida) oli yhdysvaltalainen republikaanisen puolueen poliitikko. Hän toimi maansa puolustusministerinä Vietnamin sodan aikana vuosina 1969–1973. Alun perin hänen esittämänsä oli käsite ”vietnamisointi”, joka merkitsee pyrkimystä korvata Yhdysvaltojen joukot vähitellen Etelä-Vietnamin omilla joukoilla. Tuloksena oli, että Yhdysvallat alkoi vetäytyä alueelta vuonna 1973. Laird valmistui Carleton Collegesta Minnesotassa vuonna 1942 ja palveli Yhdysvaltain laivastossa huhtikuuhun 1946. passage_en: Melvin Robert "Bom" Laird (September 1, 1922 in Omaha, Nebraska – November 16, 2016 in Florida) was an American politician of the Republican Party. He served as his country's defense minister during the Vietnam War in 1969–1973. What he initially proposed was the concept of "Vietnamization", which means the effort to gradually replace US forces with South Vietnam's own forces. As a result, the United States began to withdraw from the region in 1973. Laird graduated from Carleton College in Minnesota in 1942 and served in the United States Navy until April 1946. Laird's father, Melvin Sr. was a Wisconsin state senator, and he himself entered the Wisconsin Senate at the age of 23. He sat in the United States House of Representatives from Wisconsin's 7th congressional district from 1953 to 1969.

Java 2 Standard Edition versio 1.4 (J2SE) sisältää JDBC-rajapinnan versio 3.0:n, sekä JDBC-ODBC-sillan mallitoteutuksen. Silta tarjoaa yhteyden ODBC-rajapinnan tarjoaviin tietolähteisiin Java-virtuaalikoneesta käsin. Tämä silta on suljettua natiivikoodia (ei Javaa), ja soveltuu vain kokeelliseen käyttöön tai tilanteisiin joissa muuta ajuria ei ole tarjolla. passage_en: Java Database Connectivity (JDBC) is an interface to the Java programming language that defines a standard way for a client application to access a database. JDBC provides the methods needed for querying and updating data. JDBC is aimed at using relational databases. Java 2 Standard Edition version 1.4 (J2SE) includes version 3.0 of the JDBC interface, as well as a model implementation of the JDBC-ODBC bridge. The bridge provides a connection to data sources that provide an ODBC interface from the Java virtual machine. This bridge is a closed native code (no Java), and is only suitable for experimental use or situations where no other driver is available. The JDBC-ODBC bridge provides only some of the functionality of the JDBC 3.0 interface.

Tärkeimpiä limnologian tutkimusta ja opintoja tukevia perustieteitä ovat hydrologia, geologia, mikrobiologia, kasvitiede, eläintiede, fysiikka ja kemia. passage_en: Limnology studies inland waters: freshwater and saltwater lakes, ponds and rivers; especially the relationships and interactions between living nature and its environment. The word "limnology" comes from the Greek words Λίμνη (limne) meaning lake and λόγος (logos) meaning knowledge. The most important basic sciences supporting limnology research and studies are hydrology, geology, microbiology, botany, zoology, physics and chemistry. Limnology's sister sciences are hydrobiology and fisheries science. Seas, on the other hand, are studied by marine science, or oceanography. Limnologists work, for example, at the Finnish Environmental Center and regional environmental centers, water protection associations, municipal environmental secretaries and researchers at universities and research institutes. Limnology is taught at the University of Helsinki's Faculty of Life Sciences, Department of Bio and Environmental Sciences, where students major in "Aquatic Sciences", and at the University of Jyväskylä's Faculty of Mathematics and Natural Sciences.
